clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was initially intended to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved due to its usefulness for radio transmissions.
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city; most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today.
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo’s subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: This city is home to the famous Big Ben clock tower.
The River Thames flows through this historic capital.
fun_fact: Over 300 languages are spoken in London, making it one of the most linguistically diverse cities in the world.
The London Underground, or 'The Tube,' is the oldest metro system in the world, opening in 1863.
trivia: London has hosted the Olympics three times (1908, 1948, 2012).
Buckingham Palace has 775 rooms, including 19 state rooms.

clues: This city was once divided by a wall that fell in 1989.
It is known for its vibrant nightlife and rich history.
fun_fact: Berlin has more bridges than Venice—over 1,700 in total.
The Berlin TV Tower is the tallest structure in Germany, standing at 368 meters.
trivia: Currywurst, a popular street food, was invented in Berlin in 1949.
Berlin is nine times the size of Paris but has fewer inhabitants.

clues: Home to an iconic opera house with a sail-like design.
Famous for its stunning harbour and beaches.
fun_fact: Sydney Harbour Bridge is the widest long-span bridge in the world.
The city was originally established as a British penal colony in 1788.
trivia: Bondi Beach is one of the most famous beaches in the world.
Sydney hosts the world’s largest New Year's Eve fireworks display.

clues: This city is home to the tallest building in the world.
Famous for its luxury shopping and artificial islands.
fun_fact: Burj Khalifa stands at 828 meters, making it the tallest structure on Earth.
Dubai has an indoor ski resort inside a shopping mall.
trivia: Gold ATMs in Dubai dispense real gold bars.
Dubai's police force has luxury supercars like Lamborghinis and Ferraris.

clues: This city is known as 'The Eternal City.'
Home to an ancient amphitheater where gladiators once fought.
fun_fact: The Colosseum could hold up to 50,000 spectators in its prime.
Vatican City, the world's smallest country, is located within Rome.
trivia: Rome has more fountains than any other city in the world.
SPQR, found on Roman monuments, stands for 'The Senate and People of Rome.'

clues: This city is also a country and is known as the 'Lion City.'
Home to the world-famous Marina Bay Sands hotel and infinity pool.
fun_fact: Singapore is one of only three city-states in the world.
It is illegal to sell chewing gum in Singapore.
trivia: The Changi Airport has a rainforest and waterfall inside.
Singapore’s national symbol, the Merlion, has the body of a fish and the head of a lion.

clues: Known for its unique architecture designed by Antoni Gaudí.
A popular city for football fans, home to FC Barcelona.
fun_fact: La Sagrada Família has been under construction since 1882.
Barcelona has its own version of 'La Rambla,' a famous pedestrian street.
trivia: Barcelona was the first city to win a Royal Gold Medal for architecture.
It has one of the largest metropolitan parks in the world, Parc de Collserola.

clues: This city is home to one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
Located on the banks of the Nile River.
fun_fact: The Great Pyramid of Giza was the tallest structure in the world for 3,800 years.
Cairo is often called 'The City of a Thousand Minarets' due to its many mosques.
trivia: The Egyptian Museum in Cairo holds the treasures of King Tutankhamun.
Cairo is Africa’s largest city by population.

clues: This city is the only one in the world that spans two continents.
Known for its famous Blue Mosque and Grand Bazaar.
fun_fact: Hagia Sophia has served as a church, mosque, and museum.
The Grand Bazaar has over 4,000 shops, making it one of the largest markets in the world.
trivia: Istanbul was formerly known as Byzantium and later Constantinople.
Tulips, now associated with the Netherlands, originated in Istanbul.

clues: This city is famous for tango dancing.
Known as the 'Paris of South America' due to its architecture and culture.
fun_fact: Buenos Aires has the widest avenue in the world, Avenida 9 de Julio.
The Obelisk is one of the city's most famous landmarks.
trivia: Buenos Aires has more bookstores per person than any other city.
It is home to one of the most beautiful cemeteries in the world, Recoleta Cemetery.

clues: This city is home to K-pop and Korean drama culture.
Famous for its high-tech industry and traditional palaces.
fun_fact: Seoul’s subway system is one of the most advanced in the world.
N Seoul Tower offers panoramic views of the city.
trivia: The city is home to five UNESCO World Heritage sites.
Gangnam, made famous by the song 'Gangnam Style,' is a district in Seoul.

clues: This city is home to a famous red-colored square.
It has one of the deepest metro systems in the world.
fun_fact: The Moscow Metro stations are often called 'underground palaces' due to their elaborate decor.
The Kremlin in Moscow is both a historic fortress and the official residence of the President.
trivia: Moscow has the largest number of billionaires in Europe.
The city's famous St. Basil's Cathedral was commissioned by Ivan the Terrible.

clues: This city is known as the 'Venice of the East' due to its canals.
Home to the Grand Palace and the Emerald Buddha.
fun_fact: Bangkok's full ceremonial name is the longest city name in the world.
It has one of the world's most vibrant street food cultures.
trivia: Bangkok receives more tourists annually than any other city.
The city has a floating market where vendors sell goods from boats.

clues: This city has more skyscrapers than any other in the world.
It was once a British colony before being returned to China.
fun_fact: Hong Kong has one of the world's most efficient public transport systems.
The city hosts a nightly light and sound show called 'A Symphony of Lights'.
trivia: Dim sum, a famous Cantonese cuisine, originated here.
Victoria Peak offers the best panoramic view of the city.

clues: Home to the CN Tower, once the tallest freestanding structure.
The city is one of the most multicultural in the world.
fun_fact: Toronto has over 200 ethnic groups and 180 languages spoken.
The underground PATH system is the largest underground shopping complex in the world.
trivia: The Toronto Raptors won the NBA Championship in 2019.
Toronto is often used as a filming location for New York City in movies.

clues: Built on an ancient Aztec city, Tenochtitlan.
It has one of the largest public squares in the world, Zócalo.
fun_fact: Mexico City sinks about 10 inches each year due to its soft lakebed foundation.
The city has more museums than any other in the world.
trivia: It has the largest number of taxis in the world.
Mexico City was originally built on an island in Lake Texcoco.

clues: This city is known for its yellow trams and historic streets.
One of the oldest cities in Western Europe.
fun_fact: Lisbon was almost completely destroyed by an earthquake in 1755.
It is built on seven hills, offering great viewpoints.
trivia: Lisbon's Torre de Belém is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The city is home to the oldest operating bookstore in the world.

clues: This city is known as the 'City of Music' due to its classical composers.
Home to one of the world’s most famous coffeehouse cultures.
fun_fact: Vienna was the home of Mozart, Beethoven, and Schubert.
The city has been ranked as one of the world's most livable cities for years.
trivia: The Vienna Opera Ball is one of the most prestigious events in Europe.
Sachertorte, a famous chocolate cake, was invented here.

clues: This city is famous for its canals and bicycles.
Home to the Anne Frank House and Van Gogh Museum.
fun_fact: Amsterdam has more bicycles than residents.
The city's canals stretch over 100 kilometers.
trivia: It has over 1,500 bridges, more than Venice.
Amsterdam's houses are built on wooden stilts due to soft ground.

clues: The birthplace of democracy and home to the Acropolis.
One of the world's oldest continuously inhabited cities.
fun_fact: Athens has been inhabited for over 3,000 years.
The first modern Olympic Games were held here in 1896.
trivia: The Parthenon was originally painted in bright colors.
Ancient Greek theater originated in Athens.

clues: Built on 14 islands connected by over 50 bridges.
Home to the Nobel Prize ceremonies.
fun_fact: Stockholm is often called the 'Venice of the North'.
The city's metro stations are considered an underground art gallery.
trivia: Stockholm has more saunas than cars.
ABBA, the famous music group, originated here.

clues: Famous for Table Mountain and stunning beaches.
One of the three capital cities of South Africa.
fun_fact: Cape Town was the first city outside Europe to get Blue Flag status for its beaches.
The city has one of the world's most beautiful coastal drives, Chapman's Peak.
trivia: Cape Town's Kirstenbosch Gardens are among the most famous botanical gardens.
Nelson Mandela was imprisoned on Robben Island, located nearby.

clues: This city is home to Hollywood, the center of the film industry.
Famous for its sunny beaches and entertainment industry.
fun_fact: Los Angeles has more than 100 museums, making it a cultural hotspot.
The Hollywood sign originally read 'Hollywoodland' when it was built in 1923.
trivia: LAX is one of the busiest airports in the world.
Griffith Observatory offers a stunning view of the city and the stars.

clues: This city is the capital of Spain.
Home to the Prado Museum and the Royal Palace.
fun_fact: Madrid is the highest capital city in Europe at 667 meters above sea level.
The world's oldest restaurant, Sobrino de Botín, is located here.
trivia: Madrid has the world's second-largest metro system after London.
El Retiro Park was once reserved exclusively for Spanish royalty.

clues: This city is famous for its iconic Golden Gate Bridge.
Known for its steep hills and historic cable cars.
fun_fact: San Francisco was almost completely destroyed by an earthquake in 1906.
Alcatraz Island was once home to a maximum-security prison.
trivia: Fortune cookies were invented in San Francisco, not China.
The city has the largest Chinatown outside of Asia.

clues: This city is China's financial capital and has a famous skyline.
Home to the Bund, a historic waterfront area.
fun_fact: Shanghai has the world's fastest commercial train, the Maglev, which reaches speeds of 430 km/h.
The Oriental Pearl Tower is one of the most recognizable landmarks in the world.
trivia: Shanghai has a Disneyland park that is one of the largest in the world.
The city was once known as the 'Paris of the East'.

clues: This city is India's financial capital and home to Bollywood.
Gateway of India is one of its most famous landmarks.
fun_fact: Mumbai was originally a group of seven islands before land reclamation connected them.
Dabbawalas in Mumbai deliver 200,000 lunchboxes daily with an error rate of 1 in 16 million.
trivia: Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
Mumbai’s Marine Drive is called the 'Queen’s Necklace' due to its lights at night.

clues: This city is known as the 'Windy City'.
Home to the deep-dish pizza and famous skyline.
fun_fact: Chicago River is the only river in the world that flows backward.
The first-ever skyscraper was built in Chicago in 1885.
trivia: The city’s O'Hare Airport is one of the busiest in the world.
Chicago’s ‘L’ train system is one of the oldest in the U.S.

clues: This city is home to the tallest building in the world.
Famous for its luxury shopping and artificial islands.
fun_fact: Burj Khalifa stands at 828 meters, making it the tallest structure on Earth.
Dubai has an indoor ski resort inside a shopping mall.
trivia: Gold ATMs in Dubai dispense real gold bars.
Dubai's police force has luxury supercars like Lamborghinis and Ferraris.

clues: This city is known as the 'City of a Hundred Spires'.
Home to one of the world’s most famous astronomical clocks.
fun_fact: The Prague Castle is the largest ancient castle in the world.
Charles Bridge is said to be haunted by medieval spirits.
trivia: Beer is cheaper than water in many places in Prague.
Prague has one of the best-preserved medieval city centers in Europe.

clues: The capital of Vietnam, known for its Old Quarter.
Hoan Kiem Lake is a famous landmark in the city.
fun_fact: Hanoi is more than 1,000 years old.
The city has a unique coffee culture, including egg coffee.
trivia: The Temple of Literature was Vietnam’s first national university.
The French Quarter in Hanoi showcases colonial-era architecture.

clues: This city is known for its Viking heritage.
Home to the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony.
fun_fact: Oslo has a sculpture park dedicated entirely to human forms.
The city has some of the cleanest air of any capital in the world.
trivia: Oslo’s Opera House allows visitors to walk on its roof.
Norway's currency, the Krone, features famous explorers and ships.
